@ Michael:

<cite>"Maybe it is like reading... we do not read individual letters, rather we read words. I guess what I am saying is look at the whole."</cite>

Actually, this has been put to rest within the scientific community. We do not read word shapes. We do indeed read individual letters to recognize words. The "parallel processing model," or some variant thereof, is by far the theory best supported by experimental evidence.

Kevin Larson of the Advanced Reading group at Microsoft posted [a very concise summary of the theories of reading](http://web.archive.org/web/20150305115231/http:/www.microsoft.com/typography/ctfonts/WordRecognition.aspx), their experimental support, and references to all the studies on the Microsoft website. It is very illuminating on the subject....

Lettering and typography can share some usage in that they both attempt to present letterforms constructed as language and are meant to help convey content. One is a one-time use, the other is a repurposing of a modular system of movable elements. To create lettering, it takes a different kind of skill than it does to compose type. Part of this is technical in nature and part of this is a combination of skill, talent, and craft. The lettering artist can apply his skills to also be a typeface designer. A typographer can do the same but has more to learn about form creation to be successful(given he has the talent). I purposely omit the mention of tools since they have varied throughout the history of both disciplines (lettering being much older as well). Anyone has to learn the tools of his trade but learning the tools does not mean they will be applied to good end.

Aye, I think that one could find themselves in an awkward position, suppose, looking at a [piece](http://web.archive.org/web/20150305115231/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/chardos88/2641695626/) that incorporates Avant Garde shapes w/ fabricated flourishes, wanting to say "Hey, that's Avant Garde." In the case of the above link, it WAS Avante Garde before it was manipulated. As this was one of the top results running a flickr search of 'typography' I think an effort ought to be made to clarify, or attempt to prescribe, the meaning of the word 'typography'.

Oh, to address Eric's comment, I agree that typography and lettering mean different things, in case I haven't stressed that enough. Conflating the terms is wrong, especially if merely as a result of the word 'typography' sounding more impressive than 'lettering'. It's just that the boundaries are not clear-cut. It's possible to distinguish typography and lettering, while at the same time acknowledging all the grey areas.

I'm all for permissive rather than prescriptive use of language. Most of us here know what we would call typical, unambiguous examples of typography or lettering. Then there are all sorts of borderline cases as beautifully illustrated above. The disciplines have influenced each other plenty since the invention of type. With technological advances type is more and more able to imitate lettering, and in turn lettering may be used as elements in a typographical treatment.

As Miss Tiffany has pointed out, typography is itself a broad term, so there's more room for confusion. I think rather than try to rigorously define the terms for all situations, we should clarify what we mean by the different terms only when the need arises, and even then concede there are nebulous areas.

I agree with Michael. 'Typography' and 'Lettering' are separate entities. I think that portfolios call 'lettering' 'typography' because 'typography' has a sense of prestige imbued in it and 'lettering' sounds kind of kindergartner-ish.

Using type as a model for lettering does not make 'lettering' 'typography', that would be a misnomer. I think the easiness/popularity of outlining type and manipulating causes one to forget that the process of manipulating individual letterforms is lettering.

-Eric MacLeod
